articles.title: From silence to strength: Women leaders speak out in South Sudan
articles.summary: Scolded for wanting to go to school as a girl and dismissed or ignored as an adult, Awrelia from Wau in South Sudan has learnt to advocate for herself, her children and for the women in her community.
articles.content:
She knows what it’s like to be silenced.

Born into a family that didn’t believe in educating girls, she had to stay home while her brothers went to school. Only when she moved to Khartoum with her uncle did she get a chance to study, though not for long.

“I was forced into marriage at 14,” Awrelia said. “Even before then, some relatives scolded me just for going to school. I fought to finish primary school, but I couldn’t go any further.”

Even so, she never gave up on the value of education – especially for her daughters. “I hope they grow up to be responsible and successful women leaders. Something has to change for girls.”

© IOM/Amber Christino Awrelia at home in Wau.

Widowed mother of eight

In South Sudan, where conflict and deeply entrenched gender norms have shaped life for generations, change comes slowly – yet women like Awrelia are leading it with courage and determination.

A widowed mother of eight, she has spent years raising her children alone, often under difficult and uncertain conditions.

“Their father died when they were very young. My eldest was still in primary school,” Awrelia recounts. “I’ve been raising them alone ever since.”

In her daily life, Awrelia constantly navigates complex family dynamics, scarcity, and stigma, but she keeps going. “People expect us to endure silently. Even when women try to seek help, no one responds.”

In public spaces, the challenges are even greater. Speaking ahead of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women marked annually on 25 November, Awrelia described how women are often dismissed or ignored. “They say we’re just women, as if our voices don’t matter,” she said. “I kept quiet for years because I was afraid to speak up.”

© IOM/Geoffrey Sauke Nearly 1,400 women across South Sudan have benefitted from leadership training.

Transformative training

But even before she spoke out, Awrelia was leading in her own way – fighting for her children’s education and holding her family together. That strength deepened when she joined a women’s leadership training organized by the International Organization for Migration (IOM) in Wau.

The training is included in IOM’s gender-transformative recovery programme – part of a broader, locally led effort to strengthen women’s leadership and ensure their participation in community decisions.

Across South Sudan, women’s groups and grassroots movements have long been laying the groundwork for change. The five-day course builds on that momentum, offering women a safe space to reflect, learn, and grow together.

I learned that being a leader means treating others fairly and solving problems with patience. The training gave me courage to stand up for myself. Now I know I can lead.

“I learned that being a leader means treating others fairly and solving problems with patience,” she said. “The training gave me courage to stand up for myself. Now I know I can lead.”

Back in her community, she put her new confidence into action. Her local women’s group had nearly collapsed, but she brought it back together. Now they meet regularly to support one another and share their challenges.

Though they lack funding for income-generating activities like sewing or catering, the group offers something equally powerful: solidarity.

Women run households

In many displacement-affected areas of South Sudan, women head up to 80 per cent of households.

In Wau, Bentiu, Malakal, and other areas where IOM runs the programme, more women are stepping forward. Those who once stayed silent now speak up at meetings, support survivors of violence, and build networks to share experiences and grow together.

Awrelia has noticed a change in how she is perceived. “People recognize me now,” she said. “During a meeting with chiefs and women leaders, they mentioned my name and honoured me in front of everyone. It made me feel proud. The women I lead respect me, and I respect them.”

From homes to community halls, women like Awrelia are finding their voices and reshaping what the future can look like – for their daughters, their families, and their country.

articles.personality_title: Women in South Sudan gain leadership skills to change their communities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In South Sudan, many girls and women face strong traditions that limit their opportunities, especially in education and leadership. Years of conflict have made life harder, and many women have to raise families alone.

**What happened** – Awrelia, a woman from Wau, South Sudan, was not allowed to go to school as a child and was forced into marriage at 14. Despite these challenges, she fought for her children’s education and later joined a leadership training program run by the International Organization for Migration (IOM). This training helped her gain confidence and skills to lead a women’s group in her community.

**Impact** – Nearly 1,400 women across South Sudan have benefited from this training. Women like Awrelia are now speaking up in community meetings, supporting each other, and helping survivors of violence. Their leadership is changing how people see women and is building stronger communities where women’s voices matter.

**What's next step** – The women’s groups hope to start small businesses like sewing or catering to support themselves financially, though they currently lack funds. The program plans to continue training more women, helping them grow as leaders and create positive change in their communities.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Leadership training is helping women in South Sudan overcome barriers to speak out, support each other, and lead their communities toward a better future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des femmes au Soudan du Sud prennent la parole pour diriger leur communauté
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au Soudan du Sud, de nombreuses filles et femmes font face à des traditions fortes qui limitent leurs chances, surtout en matière d’éducation et de leadership. Les années de conflit ont rendu la vie plus difficile, et beaucoup de femmes élèvent seules leurs familles.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Awrelia, une femme de Wau au Soudan du Sud, n’a pas pu aller à l’école enfant et a été mariée de force à 14 ans. Malgré ces difficultés, elle a lutté pour l’éducation de ses enfants et a ensuite suivi une formation en leadership organisée par l’Organisation internationale pour les migrations (OIM). Cette formation lui a donné confiance et compétences pour diriger un groupe de femmes dans sa communauté.

**Impact** – Près de 1 400 femmes au Soudan du Sud ont bénéficié de cette formation. Des femmes comme Awrelia prennent maintenant la parole lors des réunions communautaires, se soutiennent entre elles et aident les survivantes de violences. Leur leadership change la façon dont les femmes sont perçues et renforce les communautés.

**En résumé** – La formation au leadership aide les femmes au Soudan du Sud à surmonter les obstacles, à s’exprimer, à se soutenir et à diriger leurs communautés vers un avenir meilleur.
articles.personality_title_es: Mujeres en Sudán del Sur adquieren habilidades de liderazgo para transformar sus comunidades
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Sudán del Sur, muchas niñas y mujeres enfrentan tradiciones que limitan sus oportunidades, especialmente en educación y liderazgo. Los años de conflicto han dificultado la vida, y muchas mujeres crían a sus familias solas.

**Qué pasó** – Awrelia, una mujer de Wau, Sudán del Sur, no pudo asistir a la escuela cuando era niña y fue obligada a casarse a los 14 años. A pesar de estos desafíos, luchó por la educación de sus hijos y luego participó en un programa de formación en liderazgo organizado por la Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM). Esta formación le dio confianza y habilidades para liderar un grupo de mujeres en su comunidad.

**Impacto** – Cerca de 1,400 mujeres en Sudán del Sur se han beneficiado de esta formación. Mujeres como Awrelia ahora hablan en reuniones comunitarias, se apoyan entre sí y ayudan a sobrevivientes de violencia. Su liderazgo está cambiando la forma en que las personas ven a las mujeres y fortaleciendo las comunidades.

**Próximo paso** – Los grupos de mujeres esperan iniciar pequeños negocios como costura o catering para apoyarse económicamente, aunque actualmente carecen de fondos. El programa planea continuar capacitando a más mujeres para que crezcan como líderes y generen cambios positivos en sus comunidades.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La formación en liderazgo está ayudando a las mujeres en Sudán del Sur a superar obstáculos, expresarse, apoyarse y liderar sus comunidades hacia un futuro mejor.

articles.title: ‘Leave no one behind’: As wealth gap widens, UN calls for new industrial deal for world’s poorest
articles.summary: Ministers and leaders from across the world’s 44 least developed countries have pledged to accelerate industrialisation that benefits all, and strengthen resilience in the face of global challenges, at an international UN conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
articles.content:
Arriving from Asia, Africa and the Caribbean, the ministers have one thing in common: they each represent one of the poorest, most vulnerable nations in the world, officially designated by the UN as least developed countries (LDCs).

The fighting seems a world away from the vast King Abdul Aziz Conference Centre in the Saudi capital, where government ministers assembled on Saturday for a family photo to mark the occasion of the Eleventh Ministerial Meeting of Least Developed Countries .

First, we need to end the war. Then, we have to restart the factories.

Like many of the world’s poorest countries, Sudan’s attempts to develop its economy have been severely hampered by conflict. Yet, even in the midst of a brutal civil war, the United Nations Industrial Development Organization ( UNIDO ) continues to offer economic development support and a path to recovery.

“First, we need to end the war. Then, we have to restart the factories,” says Basher Abdullah, advisor to Sudan’s Minister of Industry and Trade.

‘Yes to global solidarity’

“We need a decisive change of direction,” declared Gerd Müller, the Director-General of UNIDO, in his opening remarks to the assembled ministers, reminding them that industrialization is “essential for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (the 17 global goals adopted by all UN Member States in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development).and building resilience against crises.

“We need to say yes to global solidarity, to say yes to multilateralism, to say yes to keeping the gap between rich and poor from growing even wider,” added Mr. Müller.

He noted that 500 Nobel Laureates and economists are calling on the world’s leading economies (the G20, currently meeting in South Africa) to act: these leading experts have highlighted the fact that, between 2000 and 2024, the richest one per cent of the world’s population increased their wealth by 41 per cent, whilst the poorest half of the world’s population increased theirs by only one per cent.

Mr. Müller pointed out that the world’s least developed countries are particularly vulnerable to all manner of economic shocks, ranging from the climate crisis to trade tariffs and the major cuts to overseas aid and development support from the wealthiest nations.

“The losses,” he warned, “will be devastating in sectors such as textile, leather, agribusiness and equipment – all vital to livelihoods and local economies.”

Building resilience through industry

UNIDO’s mission is to help countries to weather these shocks and, by industrialising, become more resilient and improve lives: In Bangladesh, UNIDO training programmes have helped garment factories meet international standards, creating millions of jobs for women; and in Nepal, young people are being equipped with coding and digital skills, closing the digital divide.

Meanwhile, in Sudan, the agency is supporting agribusiness, targeting smallholders and entrepreneurs, and helping young people and women to access finance, readying the private sector for a time of peace and stability.

On Saturday, two major outcomes were achieved: guidelines for scaling up UNIDO support – focusing on transferring technology and knowhow – were agreed, and the ministers committed to modernising industry, finding the money to make it happen, and working more closely together in line with the UN’s global goals.

The commitments made in Riyadh mark a decisive step toward ensuring that millions of people in the world’s most vulnerable nations can thrive in an interconnected global economy.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

This has broad positive implications for reducing global inequality, supporting vulnerable populations, and advancing sustainable development goals, with concrete examples and outcomes detailed.
articles.personality_title: UN conference boosts industrial plans to help poorest countries grow stronger
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Leaders from 44 of the world’s poorest countries, called least developed countries (LDCs), met in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to discuss ways to improve their economies and face global challenges. Many of these countries struggle with poverty, conflict, and climate problems.

**What happened** – At the Eleventh Ministerial Meeting of LDCs, ministers pledged to speed up industrial growth that benefits everyone. The United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) supports their efforts by helping industries create jobs and improve skills. For example, in Bangladesh, UNIDO helped garment factories create millions of jobs for women, and in Nepal, young people are learning digital skills. Sudan, despite war, is preparing for peace by supporting farmers and small businesses.

**Impact** – This meeting is important because it brings focus to countries often left behind in global progress. Experts warn the gap between rich and poor is growing. By agreeing to work together and modernize industries, these countries aim to protect their economies from problems like climate change and trade barriers. This could improve lives by creating jobs and reducing poverty.

**What's next step** – The ministers agreed on guidelines to increase UNIDO’s support, especially by sharing technology and knowledge. They plan to find funding and cooperate more closely to reach the UN’s global goals for sustainable development by 2030.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The world’s poorest countries are joining forces, with UN support, to build stronger industries and better futures for their people.
articles.personality_title_fr: Conférence de l’ONU pour renforcer l’industrialisation des pays les plus pauvres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Des dirigeants de 44 des pays les plus pauvres, appelés pays les moins avancés (PMA), se sont réunis à Riyad, en Arabie Saoudite, pour discuter de moyens d’améliorer leurs économies et de faire face aux défis mondiaux. Beaucoup de ces pays souffrent de pauvreté, de conflits et de problèmes climatiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors de la onzième réunion ministérielle des PMA, les ministres ont promis d’accélérer la croissance industrielle qui profite à tous. L’Organisation des Nations Unies pour le développement industriel (ONUDI) soutient leurs efforts en aidant les industries à créer des emplois et à améliorer les compétences. Par exemple, au Bangladesh, l’ONUDI a aidé les usines de vêtements à créer des millions d’emplois pour les femmes, et au Népal, les jeunes apprennent des compétences numériques. Le Soudan, malgré la guerre, se prépare à la paix en soutenant les agriculteurs et les petites entreprises.

**Impact** – Cette réunion est importante car elle met l’accent sur des pays souvent oubliés dans les progrès mondiaux. Des experts alertent sur l’élargissement de l’écart entre riches et pauvres. En acceptant de travailler ensemble et de moderniser leurs industries, ces pays veulent protéger leurs économies contre des problèmes comme le changement climatique et les barrières commerciales. Cela pourrait améliorer la vie en créant des emplois et en réduisant la pauvreté.

**Prochaine étape** – Les ministres ont convenu de directives pour augmenter le soutien de l’ONUDI, notamment en partageant la technologie et le savoir-faire. Ils prévoient de trouver des financements et de coopérer davantage pour atteindre les objectifs mondiaux de développement durable des Nations Unies d’ici 2030.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les pays les plus pauvres du monde s’unissent, avec le soutien de l’ONU, pour construire des industries plus fortes et un avenir meilleur pour leurs populations.
articles.personality_title_es: Conferencia de la ONU impulsa planes industriales para fortalecer a los países más pobres
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Líderes de 44 de los países más pobres del mundo, llamados países menos desarrollados (PMD), se reunieron en Riad, Arabia Saudita, para hablar sobre cómo mejorar sus economías y enfrentar desafíos globales. Muchos de estos países enfrentan pobreza, conflictos y problemas climáticos.

**Qué pasó** – En la Undécima Reunión Ministerial de los PMD, los ministros prometieron acelerar el crecimiento industrial que beneficie a todos. La Organización de las Naciones Unidas para el Desarrollo Industrial (ONUDI) apoya estos esfuerzos ayudando a crear empleos y mejorar habilidades. Por ejemplo, en Bangladesh, la ONUDI ayudó a fábricas de ropa a generar millones de empleos para mujeres, y en Nepal, jóvenes aprenden habilidades digitales. Sudán, a pesar de la guerra, se prepara para la paz apoyando a agricultores y pequeños negocios.

**Impacto** – Esta reunión es importante porque pone atención en países que suelen quedar atrás en el progreso global. Expertos advierten que la brecha entre ricos y pobres está creciendo. Al acordar trabajar juntos y modernizar sus industrias, estos países buscan proteger sus economías de problemas como el cambio climático y barreras comerciales. Esto podría mejorar vidas creando empleos y reduciendo la pobreza.

**Próximo paso** – Los ministros acordaron pautas para aumentar el apoyo de la ONUDI, especialmente compartiendo tecnología y conocimientos. Planean conseguir fondos y cooperar más para alcanzar las metas globales de desarrollo sostenible de la ONU para 2030.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los países más pobres del mundo se unen, con apoyo de la ONU, para construir industrias más fuertes y un futuro mejor para su gente.
